title: HIGH INVOLVEMENT MANAGEMENT, EMPLOYEE WELL-BEING & ORGANISATIONAL PERFORMANCE
abstractText:
High involvement management, lean production and family-friendly practices are viewed by academics and policy-makers as critical ways of improving both the individual’s well-being and the organisation’s efficiency, and are frequently treated as related concepts. For example, family-friendly management may enhance employee commitment which is required for high involvement management to be effective.

The objectives of the project are to examine:

  1. the changing nature of high involvement, lean production and family-friendly management, including the extent to which they are used together and the contexts where they are found eg are they associated with certain competitive strategies, management values, and trade unionism;
  2. the impact that these forms of management have on (a) employee well-being, (b) commitment, and (c) job satisfaction; 
  3. the association between these forms of management and organisational performance, and whether this depends on their having an effect on employee well-being), 
  4.  Whether the relationships between these forms of management and well being or performance have changed in the recent past.

The study will use data from the Workplace Employee Relations Surveys of 1998 and 2004.  Analysis procedures will involve state of the art statistical analysis, including latent variable analysis, multi-level modelling, path analysis and configuration analysis.
